body:
Yeah, there's definitely something going on there.  I don't think that it's the palette, since they're both full color RGB, non-palettized images. It looks like the implementation in PcxDecode is pretty close to the reference version, so I'm not too worried about that. 

It looks like there's an off by one error in the G and B  bands. I'm guessing that it's because there's an odd number of bytes, so the even stride length is throwing something off. Comparing to an imagemagick converted pcx->png, the first 12 bytes of each band look like:

```
R band
.pcx b'\xb1\xa8\x9c\x8d}uZh\xb6\xa4NX'
.png b'\xb1\xa8\x9c\x8d}uZh\xb6\xa4NX'
G band
.pcx b'\x00\xa4\x9c\x95\x87vnVd\xb0\x9eK'
.png b'\xa4\x9c\x95\x87vnVd\xb0\x9eKS'
B band
.pcx b'H\x00\x9a\x95\x93\x84qkTc\xb0\x9e'
.png b'\x9a\x95\x93\x84qkTc\xb0\x9eJO'
```

That \x00 byte really looks like the last padding byte of the previous band's row.  I think that likely we need to make the image width match the stride, at least while decoding the band interleaved rows.

(for reference, http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/PCX , and http://web.archive.org/web/20100206055706/http://www.qzx.com/pc-gpe/pcx.txt )

Thanks wiredfool! That's it!!
I'm going to study the format but I think I'm beginning to understand, the first row is red because b and g are 0. (but it is vertical? it't by column? the color planes are by row or col?)
I thought it was a problem of "offset". Is the image malformed or out of standard or there is a bug in the reference that pillow implemented? I see that the example code in the txt is really similar

from wiki:
PCX image data are compressed using run-length encoding (RLE), a simple lossless compression algorithm that collapses a series of three or more consecutive bytes with identical values into a two-byte pair...

It could be a RLE problem?

Anyway I'm going to check the implementation ;) thanks again!

If the RLE decompression was wrong, we'd have more wrong than just this, especially wince the other one works. I _think_ what's happening is that in the image file, one row looks like this for an odd pixel size once decompressed from RLE:
(P == padding, RGB = image bytes)

```
RRRRRRRRRP
GGGGGGGGGP
BBBBBBBBBP
```

(note, 10 bytes wide)

And what we're winding up with is:

```
RRRRRRRRR
PGGGGGGGG
PBBBBBBBB
```

(note 9 bytes wide)

which then gets decoded to:

```
RPPA RGBA RGBA ...
```

What's probably happening is that the PcxDecoder is returning all the bytes for in the stride, including the padding, for the raw decoder to take from line by line and convert to the standard RGBA int for a pixel. The raw decoder is taking that byte stream and not discarding the padding byte.  The only problem with that theory is that the B values are only one byte off, and not two. 

If I'm right, any .pcx with an odd pixel width is going to do this. (though, to be fair, I could be wrong and that could still be the case, but I think it would be good confirmation)

You are right. I've extracted other images from the game archive.
and every  odd [W]x[H] has this problem.

here is the archive with more pcx to carry tests : https://db.tt/hQw3eN0J

I'm not sure but I think that at PcxImagePlugin.py, line 128

```
# bytes per plane
stride = (im.size[0] * bits + 7) // 8
```

if width is odd, it should be + 1 to that calculation. anyway isn't the stride is in the header? after the number of planes, offset 0x42.

that's only the save function but it may be a mismatch with the original pcx

tomorrow I'm gonna do some tests ;)
Well, that particular line is in the _save routine, so while it's a bug, it's not your main problem right now.

It works :+1: thanks!
for the test image, gimp can save any image to pcx format.
Unfortunately, both Gimp and ImageMagick both write images with odd strides, which doesn't trigger this bug.

issue.title: Correctly handle odd sized PCX Images
issue.body:
Fixes #523.

Handles both opening and saving odd sized images with an even stride, as per the spec.

issue.title: Handle PCX images with an odd stride
issue.body:
Resolves #5203

The [PCX specification](https://web.archive.org/web/20100206055706/http://www.qzx.com/pc-gpe/pcx.txt) states that 'BytesPerLine' 'MUST be an EVEN number.'
The two images that are failing in the issue list the BytesPerLine as 371 and 409. So they are malformed.

This may not be uncommon, since it has been [noted in an earlier issue](https://github.com/python-pillow/Pillow/issues/523#issuecomment-35229372)
> Unfortunately, both Gimp and ImageMagick both write images with odd strides

The images started to fail after #5174 (ping @wiredfool) abandoned the image's reported stride in favour of calculating it ourselves. This PR relaxes that slightly, by allowing the reported stride to tell us whether this is a well-formed image with an even stride, or a malformed image with an odd stride.

If the thinking is that we should just reject the malformed images, then this can be closed.
